current-chamber.#text: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

official-title.#text: To provide grants to promote financial literacy.

sponsor.#tail: introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the

committee-name.#text: Committee on Health, Education, Labor, and Pensions

short-title.#text:
Financial and Economic Literacy
			 Improvement Act of 2013

text.#text:
This Act may be cited as
			 the

An eligible entity that receives a grant under this
				section shall use 75 percent of such grant funds to award subgrants to eligible
				local entities.

An eligible local entity that desires to receive a
				subgrant under this paragraph shall submit an application to the eligible
				entity at such time, in such manner, and accompanied by such information as the
				eligible entity may require.

administer
				financial literacy assessments on not less than an annual basis in, at a

implement

may use the

text.#text:
An
				eligible local entity that receives a subgrant under this paragraph shall
				include in the annual report card under

An eligible entity that receives a grant under this
				section shall use 25 percent of such grant funds to carry out the
				following:

The development
				of financial literacy standards in not less than 3 grade levels, including not
				less than 1 grade level in elementary school, not less than 1 grade level in
				middle school, and not less than 1 grade level in high school.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that are valid, reliable, and comparable across the
				State.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965/s:5538/ss:e/p:2/sp:A

text.#text:
The development
				of appropriate financial literacy assessments in the grade levels determined
				under

Teacher
				professional development programs to embed financial literacy or personal
				finance education into core academic subjects.

An evaluation of
				the impact of financial literacy or personal finance education on students’
				understanding of financial literacy concepts.

An eligible entity that receives a grant under this section
				shall provide, from non-Federal sources, an amount equal to 25 percent of the
				amount of the grant award to carry out activities required under this
				section.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}fund.#text:
$125,000,000 for each of fiscal years 2014 through
				2019

shall award grants under this section in

text.#text: The

An eligible entity that receives a grant under this section
				shall use the grant funds to develop and implement financial literacy
				education, activities, student organizations, or counseling that increase
				student knowledge in consumer, economic, and personal financial
				concepts.
